thread.title: Sam Sachdeva: Appeal of Peter Thiel as NZ citizen is plain to see
thread.title_full: Sam Sachdeva: Appeal of Peter Thiel as NZ citizen is plain to see

author: Sam Sachdeva
title: Sam Sachdeva: Appeal of Peter Thiel as NZ citizen is plain to see
text:
But beneath all the bluster, it's hard to escape the feeling this may be much ado about nothing. SHANNON STAPLETON 
US President Donald Trump sits with PayPal co-founder and Facebook board member Peter Thiel during a meeting with technology leaders at Trump Tower in New York. 
After all, it's not as if Thiel slipped the Government a burlap sack stuffed with $20 notes in exchange for a New Zealand passport and a lifestyle block. 
He's been a resident since 2006 and a permanent resident since 2009, giving him more than a decade of formal ties to the country. 
During that time, Thiel has poured millions of dollars into Kiwi companies and donated $1 million to the Christchurch earthquake appeal fund following the city's devastating earthquakes. EMMA DANGERFIELD/FAIRFAX NZ 
As Prime Minister Bill English said this week, we're better off as a country if people like Thiel want to come here. 
He has promoted New Zealand on the world stage as a utopia, praising our "stark beauty" and "number eight wire mentality". Ad Feedback 
Unlike William Yan and Kim Dotcom, two previous high-profile migration cases, Thiel is not wanted by any law enforcement agencies. 
In fact, his biggest crimes appear to be (in order) backing new US President Donald Trump and, well, being a bit of a weirdo. 
But like it or not - and I certainly don't - Trump isn't disappearing any time soon, and having a Kiwi as a close confidante may reap rewards that endure well past the Orange One departing the Oval Office. 
As for Thiel's eccentricities, which include plans to inject himself with young people's blood so he can live until he's 120, there's no denying he's out there. 
But if weirdness was a disqualifying factor for citizenship, there'd be more than a few native-born Kiwis looking over their shoulders (including some of our politicians). 
BETTER OFF WITH PEOPLE LIKE THIEL 
As Prime Minister Bill English said this week, we're better off as a country if people like Thiel want to come here to invest in Kiwi businesses and donate to local causes. 
We're far from alone in providing a path to citizenship for the wealthy, either. 
Australia, Canada, the UK and the US all offer "investor visas" for people willing to pour money into the country. 
Others go further, offering what are essentially cash for citizenship programmes. 
Thankfully we're not at that level, nor should we be. 
But encouraging the best and brightest to lay down roots in New Zealand is something we should embrace, rather than taking up pitchforks against those whose ideologies we disagree with. 
The Government still must front up with the reasons for granting Thiel citizenship under "exceptional circumstances". 
Their reluctance to release information so far does add a shred of doubt, although the Department of Internal Affairs has said it will release documents about Thiel next week. 
FOCUS ON VULNERABLE, NOT WEALTHY 
Critics wanting to target the Government over migration should instead focus on the shameful exploitation of vulnerable immigrants. 
Those like Pritpal Singh, who came here in search of a brighter future but instead found himself working 80-hour weeks for as little as $25 a day , are being badly let down by the system. 
Whether an American billionaire or an Indian student, anyone who wants to come to New Zealand, follow our laws and make a positive difference should be welcomed with open arms. 
Instead of obsessing over the political peccadilloes of someone like Thiel, let's focus on those like Pritpal who really need our help. - Stuff
